sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Understanding the experiences of women participating in residential alcohol and other drug (AOD) treatment is important in ensuring treatment effectively meets women's needs. Patient‐reported experience measures aid in assessing women's experiences of treatment but are often used to quantify women's treatment satisfaction without additional context regarding specific treatment experiences. This study examined the relationship between the domains of the Patient Reported Experience Measure for Addiction Treatment (PREMAT) and overall treatment satisfaction, including whether relationships differed by gender.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: N = 138 participants (30.9% women) from a not‐for‐profit residential AOD treatment service completed a survey regarding their experiences of and satisfaction with treatment, including the PREMAT. Descriptives, chi‐square and Mann–Whitney U statistics examined gender differences in demographics. A generalised linear model assessed the relationship between PREMAT domain scores and overall treatment satisfaction (Client Satisfaction Questionnaire), controlling for age and weeks in treatment, including whether relationships differed by gender. Relative weight statistics examined the relative statistical importance of each PREMAT domain to overall satisfaction.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: There were no gender differences on PREMAT item, domain or total scores. Controlling for age and weeks in treatment, significant predictors of overall treatment satisfaction were the PREMAT ‘self‐determination and empowerment’ and ‘personal responsibility’ domains. The impact of ‘personal responsibility’ on overall satisfaction was weaker for women compared to men.

sec.title: Discussion and Conclusions
sec.p: Fostering individualised care and support, self‐determination, empowerment and personal responsibility for care, are important aspects of residential treatment for both men and women. Further development of women‐specific PREMs that address gendered experiences of treatment is warranted.

list-item.p: Patient‐reported experience measures are under‐utilised in substance use research.
Need to examine overall treatment satisfaction and gendered experiences that impact this satisfaction.
Self‐determination and empowerment are essential for men and women's treatment satisfaction.
Personal responsibility is less important to women's treatment satisfaction than men's.
Further work is needed to develop patient‐reported experience measures that capture women's specific and unique experiences.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Substance use disorders (SUD) are a leading cause of death and disability [1, 2], with an estimated 39.5 million people meeting SUD criteria worldwide [3]. Residential alcohol and other drug (AOD) treatment services provide structured care and support for people with SUDs who would benefit from 24/7 support in a more controlled environment due to complex social, physical and emotional factors [4, 5, 6]. Residential programs generally include withdrawal support, individual and group psychological support, mutual self‐help and supported reintegration into the community [5, 6]. Research has demonstrated the effectiveness of residential treatment in improving outcomes across a range of substance use and functioning domains [5, 6, 7]. While indicators of ‘success’ (e.g., abstinence, symptom improvement and treatment retention) are important in evaluating residential services, health care's shift towards person‐centred care has also led to a greater appreciation of client needs, preferences, values and experiences.

Person‐centred care has been defined as ‘care that is respectful of, and responsive to, the preferences, needs and values of patients and consumers’ [8, p. 1] or ‘treating patients as individuals and as equal partners in the business of healing’ [9, p. 114]. Person‐centred care is particularly important among vulnerable populations, including people with SUDs, with people participating in AOD treatment consistently expressing their appreciation for having ‘a voice’ in their care [10, 11]. There has also been an increased understanding of the impact of gender on experiences of substance use and treatment, with it now generally recognised that the social construction of gender, and the specific and complex experiences of women, cannot be ignored [12, 13, 14]. For example, women who use substances often experience collective alienation regarding their role in society [15], as well as significant societal expectations [16], stigma [17, 18], guilt and fear [19, 20], and blame [20]. Coupled with the historically patriarchal nature of AOD research and treatment, this highlights the importance of understanding women's unique experiences of AOD treatment, particularly in order to advance person‐centred care and ensure current treatment models are effectively meeting the needs of women.

Measures which significantly aid in a comprehensive person‐centred care assessment include patient‐reported experience measures (PREM; [21]), which gather important information on the client's experience of receiving treatment [22]. PREMs can include questions regarding client experience (i.e., factual responses about what did or did not occur during treatment) and client satisfaction (i.e., subjective responses about the quality of care) [23, 24]. However, research has highlighted a general under‐utilisation of PREMs in AOD research and treatment, particularly among women [25]. Additionally, the reporting of PREM results often only includes an overall ‘satisfaction’ score, without additional information regarding client experiences. For women, it has been noted that these results and conclusions often do not align with women's experiences where qualitative or mixed methods are used [24, 25]. Measures and methods which prioritise overall satisfaction scores are useful in making broad conclusions regarding the ability of treatment services to adequately cater to women. However, PREMs which focus more explicitly on women's unique experiences of treatment, rather than a reduction of women's experiences to a single numerical score, can more meaningfully inform clinical practice and service provision. As such, it has been suggested that the use of PREMs should include analysis of overall treatment satisfaction as well as examination of women's experiences with, or perceptions of, specific aspects of treatment which may impact this overall satisfaction [25].

PREMs have been developed and used across many health care settings. However, Kingsley and Patel [22] note that choosing the correct PREM tool for the specific population and the data to be collected is crucial in obtaining relevant and meaningful experience data. In AOD research, the generally limited use of PREMs as well as the absence of AOD‐specific PREMs have been identified as significant issues [26]. Hinsley et al. [27] helped to address these issues by developing a PREM specifically for residential AOD treatment services—the Patient Reported Experience Measure for Addiction Treatment (PREMAT). The PREMAT was developed through extensive consultation with people engaged in residential AOD treatment services using a process guided by recognised principles of person‐centred care [27]. The resulting measure assesses client's experiences and satisfaction across specific aspects of person‐centred care; for example, fast access to reliable health care, involvement in decisions and respect for preferences, attention to physical and environmental needs (see [28]). Kelly et al. [29] conducted a preliminary psychometric evaluation and validation of the PREMAT among 178 participants (40.4% women) across six Australian residential treatment services and found that the PREMAT is a valid measure of experience, with ‘excellent’ internal consistency and ‘strong’ test–retest reliability. Principal component analysis identified six underlying domains: individualised support; self‐determination and empowerment; program structure; treatment environment; coordination of care; and personal responsibility [29]. There was also a strong correlation between the PREMAT and other measures of client satisfaction [29].

The structure of the PREMAT provides a useful opportunity to examine client's experiences with specific aspects of residential treatment across a range of domains. In addition, little research exists that determines the relative importance or impact of different aspects of treatment on overall client satisfaction, including whether these impacts are gender specific. As such, the aim of the current study is to examine the relationship between each domain of the PREMAT and overall treatment satisfaction, including whether these relationships differ by gender. This study will provide valuable insights regarding the different experiences of residential treatment for men and women and inform service provision and potential adaptations to ensure men and women are satisfied with their care. This study will also contribute to improving the evidence base for the PREMAT as a measure of client experiences in residential AOD treatment, particularly for women.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This study followed the Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology (STROBE) guidelines for cross‐sectional research (see Appendix A) and received approval from the University of Wollongong Human Research Ethics Committee (2021/208).

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: Data for this study was collected from a not‐for‐profit organisation that provides treatment for up to 84 adults experiencing problematic alcohol or substance use. The residential program operates within a modified Therapeutic Community model, grounded in the ‘community as method’ philosophy, which emphasises mutual self‐help, structured routines and the use of the peer community to facilitate behavioural and psychological change [30, 31]. This approach relies on a structured daily schedule and defined roles that support residents in developing accountability and emotional regulation through communal living [32]. The program accommodates men and women, and follows a stepped‐care approach over a 9–12 months period. It offers integrated support for mental and physical health needs, including a withdrawal management unit, specialised therapy groups, the Residential College, individual and group counselling and access to specialised family support. While the organisation also delivers community‐based programs, this study focuses exclusively on the residential treatment setting.

sec.title: Recruitment and Data Collection
sec.p: Recruitment of participants for the current study involved collaboration between researchers and residential service staff. Residential clients were recruited on site, with data collection completed anonymously either online via Qualtrics or a paper survey which was later transferred to Qualtrics. Data was collected as part of broader routine quality improvement audits and followed a census approach, with data collected at a given point in time among residents available at the service during recruitment, rather than at a specific moment in individuals' treatment process. Data was collected in two waves: from July to August 2021, and July to November 2024. There were no significant changes in the structure of the program between the two time points.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Inclusion criteria for the current study included being aged over 18, currently participating in residential treatment at the included not‐for‐profit service, and providing informed consent to participate. There were no exclusion criteria. A total of 138 clients completed the survey, including 43 (30.9%) women.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: Demographics: Demographic items were adapted from the Your Experience of Service (YES) survey [33] and other Australian studies in residential AOD settings [34]. Demographic data was collected regarding participant's gender identity (man, woman, other), main language spoken at home (English, other), age (in years) and highest level of education (high school or less, TAFE/Trade, University). Substance of concern included six response options (alcohol, amphetamine, heroin, cannabis, cocaine and other). On the web‐based survey, respondents were permitted to indicate only one response, whereas on the paper‐based survey, multiple participants indicated more than one drug of concern. Data regarding the number and percentage of participants reporting any use (yes/no) of the six substance use options was assessed for descriptive purposes only. Questions were also asked regarding participant's length of current treatment episode (in weeks), and whether they had previously accessed treatment for their mental health (including whether a diagnosis was provided).

Patient Reported Experience Measure for Addiction Treatment [27]. The PREMAT is a 23‐item measure used to assess people's experiences of their current residential treatment episode. Items are scored on a Likert scale from 1 (‘strongly disagree’) to 5 (‘strongly agree’). Item scores are summed to produce a total score ranging from 23 to 115, with higher scores indicating greater levels of positive experience associated with treatment engagement. Scores can also be categorised into groups: poor experience (23–74), average experience (75–87), good experience (88–99) and very good experience (100–115) [29]. PREMAT domain scores were calculated by summing responses to the relevant items for each of the six domains identified by Kelly et al. [29]. These domains are: (i) individualised support (e.g., support, enough one‐on‐one sessions, help for difficulties and being treated like a person instead of an addict); (ii) self‐determination and empowerment (e.g., increased awareness, improved self‐perception, feeling understood and being able to cope with everyday life); (iii) program structure (e.g., structured days, schedules, opportunities to exercise and, time to focus on recovery); (iv) treatment environment (e.g., privacy, nutrition and cleanliness); (v) co‐ordination of care (e.g., involvement of family and friends, being linked up with other services); and (vi) personal responsibility (e.g., knowing what the rules are and consequences for breaking rules). The PREMAT has been validated for use within residential AOD treatment services and shows good internal consistency, test–retest reliability and convergent validity [29, 35]. All PREMAT items, including their domain loading, are presented in Appendix B.

Client Satisfaction Questionnaire‐8 (CSQ‐8; [36]). The CSQ‐8 was developed as a brief measure of global satisfaction. Items are scored on a Likert scale from 1 (‘low satisfaction’) to 4 (‘high satisfaction’). Item scores are summed to produce a total score, ranging from 8 to 32, with higher total scores indicating greater satisfaction with care. The CSQ‐8 has high internal consistency and concurrent validity in mental health outpatient settings [37] and has been validated for use within inpatient populations [34, 38, 39].

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Descriptive statistics were used to examine the demographics of all participants who completed the survey, including Chi‐square tests with Bonferroni correction and t‐tests to examine proportional and mean differences between men and women. Among the 138 participants who completed the survey, 127 had complete PREMAT data. For individual PREMAT items, the item with the highest amount of missing data was item 22 (‘I have been linked up with other services to support me when I leave this program’), with a 92.8% response rate. On a participant level, missing data ranged from 1 item to 10 items. Two participants missing three or fewer PREMAT item responses out of the 23 total items (i.e., < 10% of total PREMAT items) had values for these items imputed based on the mean of their completed PREMAT items [40, 41]. Participants missing more than three PREMAT item responses were excluded (n = 9), resulting in a sample size of 129 for all PREMAT‐related analyses. Due to non‐normality of the data and unequal group sizes, Mann–Whitney U tests were used to examine median differences between men and women on PREMAT item, domain and total scores.

CSQ and PREMAT data was non‐normally distributed and negatively skewed. Transformations (including reflection and log10, square root and Box‐Cox) did not remedy the non‐normality of the data. For more robust analysis of the non‐normal data, a generalised linear model was used to determine the relationship between PREMAT domains and overall CSQ scores, including whether these relationships are moderated by gender. The model also controlled for age (in years) and length of current treatment episode (in weeks). Parameter estimates were obtained using maximum likelihood estimation. Goodness of fit statistics were examined to determine model fit, including log‐likelihood, Akaike Information Criterion, Consistent Akaike Information Criterion and Bayesian Information Criterion. Coefficients for each predictor variable were assessed, with a significance level set at p < 0.05. The proposed model is presented in Appendix C.

Relative importance analysis was conducted to assess the proportional contribution of each of the PREMAT domains to overall treatment satisfaction [42, 43]. The relative weight statistic has been shown to provide robust estimates of the relative importance of predictor variables, particularly when those predictor variables are correlated [43]. This has been found in both simulation and primary studies [44, 45]. The statistical assumptions and method are described elsewhere [42, 43, 44]. Tonidandel and LeBreton [44] developed an interactive website for conducting relative importance analysis that performs calculations using the open‐source R statistical package as its backbone (https://www.scotttonidandel.com/rwa‐web). This free website was used to conduct the relative importance analysis, with CSQ total score entered as the outcome and PREMAT domain scores entered as predictors. As suggested, 10,000 bootstraps at a p < 0.05 level were utilised to obtain the raw relative weight for each predictor, which were then rescaled to relative weight percentages (indicating percentage in total possible variance (i.e., 100%) in total satisfaction that each predictor explains). This was calculated for the overall sample and then for men and women separately, with raw relative weights compared between men and women to assess gender differences.

sec.title: Participant Demographics
sec.p: Table 1 shows participant characteristics (N = 138). Participants had a mean age of 37.33 (SD = 11.07) and treatment duration of 15.67 weeks (SD = 18.64). Over one‐third (64.7%) reported high school or less as their highest level of education, and almost 40% reported having received a mental health diagnosis in the past. The most commonly reported substance of concern was amphetamines (45.7%), followed by alcohol (37.2%). A significantly higher proportion of women reported amphetamine use compared to men (61.0% vs. 38.6%). More women reported a mental health diagnosis compared to men (58.1% vs. 29.5%), and women were more likely to report TAFE/Trade as their highest level of education (34.9% vs. 20.0%).

sec.title: Gender Differences PREMAT Item, Domain and Total Scores
sec.p: Among participants with valid PREMAT data (n = 129), PREMAT total scores ranged from 42 to 115, with an average score of 90.33 (SD = 16.13), indicating ‘good’ experiences of treatment. There were no differences between men and women on any PREMAT domain score or total score (Table 2). There were no gender differences observed at the item level (Appendix B). A strong negative skew was observed for PREMAT items, domain scores and total scores, indicating a clustering of high‐score responses.

sec.title: Associations Between PREMAT Domains and Overall Treatment Satisfaction
sec.p: A generalised linear model was conducted to determine the predictive relationship between PREMAT domains and overall treatment satisfaction (CSQ total score), including the interaction between PREMAT domains and gender, controlling for age and weeks in treatment. The addition of the predictors (i.e., gender, age, weeks in treatment, each of the six PREMAT domains, interaction between gender and each domain) significantly improved the model compared to the intercept‐only model (likelihood ratio chi‐square = 129.15, p < 0.001) with improved goodness of fit indicators. A test of model effects indicated that, controlling for age (p = 0.469) and length of treatment (p = 0.383), significant predictors of overall treatment satisfaction (total CSQ score) included self‐determination and empowerment (Wald = 18.833, p < 0.001), personal responsibility (Wald = 8.258, p = 0.004) and the interaction term between gender and personal responsibility (Wald = 5.419, p = 0.020).

Table 3 shows the parameter estimates of the final model, adjusted for age and length of treatment. For every 1‐point increase in total self‐determination and empowerment domain score, there is an estimated 0.6‐point increase in total satisfaction, or a relative increase of 2.5% (CSQ range 9–32, B = 0.601, p = 0.003). Similarly, every 1‐point increase in total personal responsibility domain score is associated with an estimated 1.5‐point increase in total satisfaction, a relative increase of 6.4% (B = 1.523, p < 0.001). There was also a significant interaction effect of gender on the relationship between personal responsibility and treatment satisfaction, indicating that the effect of personal responsibility on overall treatment satisfaction is weaker for women compared to men (B = −1.380, p = 0.020).

sec.p: Relative importance analysis confirmed these results, indicating a significant difference in the relative importance/weight of personal responsibility on overall satisfaction for men compared to women, where personal responsibility explained 26.7% of the total possible variance in treatment satisfaction for men, compared to 7.5% for women (Table 4). Overall, the PREMAT domains explained 64.8% of the variance in overall treatment satisfaction.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Research has demonstrated that the under‐utilisation of PREMs in AOD research and treatment contributes to a situation where women's experiences are not properly understood, or where their satisfaction with treatment is over‐stated [24, 25]. This is particularly evident when women's overall satisfaction scores obtained using PREMs are compared with qualitative or mixed‐methods research regarding women's experiences of treatment [24, 25]. However, PREMs provide the opportunity to examine specific aspects of clients' experiences, how these experiences inform and impact their overall satisfaction and engagement with treatment, and whether these relationships are gender specific. Given the relationship between treatment satisfaction and treatment retention and outcomes [46, 47, 48, 49, 50], understanding and improving client experiences shown to impact overall satisfaction is an important priority for residential services, and will also aid in advancing person‐centred care approaches across the residential treatment sector.

Results of the current study demonstrated that the PREMAT domain of ‘self‐determination and empowerment’ is a significant predictor of overall treatment satisfaction, regardless of gender. Experiences related to increased awareness and understanding of AOD use, involvement in care planning, feeling supported by staff and other residents and being supported to cope with everyday life, emerged as more important to overall treatment satisfaction than treatment or process‐based experiences like the structure of the program, schedules, privacy or physical aspects of the environment. It is recognised that the implementation of some of these practices within routine service delivery may be challenging, particularly within a field where disempowerment, distrust and stigma can be common [8, 51, 52], and where time, financial and resource constraints may impact the degree of client involvement [53, 54]. Despite challenges in designing and delivering treatment to clients with diverse and distinct needs, particularly women [55], clinical standards and a commitment to person‐centred care warrant individualised care planning and collaborative decision making throughout all stages of treatment [56]. For women, fostering knowledge of personal and social identities, awareness of gender‐role stereotypes and oppression, expression of traditional feminine characteristics and awareness of unequal power statuses, may also play important roles in increasing self‐empowerment [57, 58]. This is particularly important given the historically patriarchal nature of AOD treatment, as well as historical approaches to AOD treatment that include shame‐based practices, moralistic frameworks and religious influences, which may have been particularly exclusionary or punitive towards women [12].

The current results also demonstrated that personal responsibility has a weaker impact on overall treatment satisfaction for women, compared to men. This domain focuses on the rules of the treatment program—whether the rules are sensible, clearly communicated and have clear consequences if not met. These results may be interpreted in the context of women's socialisation, societal expectations and gender roles, where women are often more concerned with social harmony, maintaining order and group cohesion, resulting in greater adherence to established rules and norms within society [59]. As such, entering a residential treatment setting with structured rules and consequences for not adhering to such rules may not be a new or unique experience for women, and consequently, may not influence their overall treatment satisfaction as much as for men. While this is speculative and represents an important area for further research, these results highlight the importance of reasonable rules that are clearly communicated, particularly for men within a residential, therapeutic community setting. Further research should consider whether this is similar for men participating in other models of care and explore potential explanations for this gendered relationship between personal responsibility and treatment satisfaction.

Women in the current study reported high satisfaction with treatment across all PREMAT domains. Satisfaction scores provide useful information regarding the overall satisfaction of clients engaged in treatment. However, the focus on individual experiences that PREMs afford can directly inform service provisions and improvements based on an identification of experiences that may be amenable to change [25]. While our research had no qualitative component, parallels can also be drawn between the general misalignment of quantitative satisfaction results and qualitative experience findings for women [24, 25]. The PREMAT was developed in consultation with men and women engaged in residential treatment services. However, all suggestions and considerations were combined into a single measure [27]. The current results demonstrate that the PREMAT captures some treatment experiences that are salient for both men and women. However, it may be that the PREMAT, and other measures of satisfaction/experience, are lacking in consideration of gendered experience or experiences that may be specific to women, for example, heightened experience of stigma due to being a woman who uses substances, gendered interactions with staff, operational or logistical considerations for women with children and/or families, considerations regarding pregnancy and access to female specific services or care within a treatment setting [25]. Consistent with centring lived and living experience in research and treatment, qualitative methods can capture the complexity and nuances of women's experiences of treatment. However, the time and resource intensity of qualitative methods may render them less feasible in a clinical, service delivery setting [60]. The development of women‐specific measures that address gendered issues and experiences that are more relevant to women may allow for a quicker understanding of a service's ability to meet women's needs [25]. On a larger scale, such measures may play an important role in benchmarking and progress monitoring [61], which may influence service development and improvements for women across the residential AOD treatment sector. In addition, the PREMAT domains explained around 65% of the variance in overall treatment satisfaction, indicating that there are other factors or experiences that may play an important role in informing client's satisfaction with treatment that are not captured by the PREMAT, for both men and women.

The current study had several strengths and limitations. Strengths of this study include the use of validated measures of satisfaction/experience for residential services, including the relatively novel PREMAT measure, specifically developed with men and women engaged in residential treatment, although there is potential for improved gender‐specificity. The study also utilised robust methods to address an identified gap in current PREM research, specifically analysing the relationships between client experiences and overall treatment satisfaction within a single treatment episode at a given point in time. However, recruiting from a single service limits the generalisability of findings to clients accessing different services. The census approach to data collection may also limit the reliability of the findings, as data was collected at a certain point in time rather than focusing on the specific stages of treatment or recovery of each participant. Future research may consider how being in different stages of treatment impacts clients' experiences of care. There was also limited variability in PREMAT domain scores and overall satisfaction scores were high, which is quite common in AOD treatment settings [24, 62]. Although this research was led externally, data were collected anonymously and clients were free to decline participation, it is possible clients responded in a socially desirable manner. It is possible that clients may have been unwilling to speak of negative experiences, or exaggerated their satisfaction, due to difficulties in accessing treatment (e.g., due to disparities in treatment demand vs. treatment places, long waitlists, etc.). This may also be influenced by factors such as parenting concerns, fear of child removal or family restoration concerns and access to family‐inclusive services, which may shape women's experiences of treatment and contribute to the positive‐leaning nature of the data. Future research should consider examining these additional factors to better understand their impact on treatment engagement and reported treatment satisfaction. Results may also be subject to selection bias as participants had been in treatment for an average of over 15 weeks. Clients who left treatment prior to data collection, or opted not to participate, may have had different experiences. Finally, the substance of concern variable should be interpreted with caution, with the number of clients reporting substances of concern likely being under‐represented due to inconsistencies in web‐based versus paper‐based survey collection.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Patient‐reported experience measures are a valuable tool in advancing and committing to person‐centred care and provide opportunities to examine specific client experiences which impact overall treatment satisfaction. The development of PREMs which are more applicable to women may allow for quicker and more effective assessment of women's experiences of treatment. Further research should be conducted regarding the potential of PREMs (whether existing or newly developed) to identify gendered experiences of treatment across the residential AOD sector. Increasing individualised care and support and fostering self‐determination, empowerment and personal responsibility for care are important aspects of residential treatment for both men and women.

app.p:
STROBE Statement—Checklist of items that should be included in reports of cross‐sectional studies.
Item no.RecommendationPage #
Title and abstract1(a) Indicate the study's design with a commonly used term in the title or the abstract1
(b) Provide in the abstract an informative and balanced summary of what was done and what was found2
Introduction
Background/rationale2Explain the scientific background and rationale for the investigation being reported4–5
Objectives3State specific objectives, including any prespecified hypotheses5
Methods
Study design4Present key elements of study design early in the paper6
Setting5Describe the setting, locations, and relevant dates, including periods of recruitment, exposure, follow‐up, and data collection6
Participants6(a) Give the eligibility criteria, and the sources and methods of selection of participants6
Variables7Clearly define all outcomes, exposures, predictors, potential confounders, and effect modifiers. Give diagnostic criteria, if applicable6–7
Data sources/measurement8a For each variable of interest, give sources of data and details of methods of assessment (measurement). Describe comparability of assessment methods if there is more than one group6–7
Bias9Describe any efforts to address potential sources of bias8
Study size10Explain how the study size was arrived at6
Quantitative variables11Explain how quantitative variables were handled in the analyses. If applicable, describe which groupings were chosen and why8–9
Statistical methods12(a) Describe all statistical methods, including those used to control for confounding8–9
(b) Describe any methods used to examine subgroups and interactions8–9
(c) Explain how missing data were addressed8–9
(d) If applicable, describe analytical methods taking account of sampling strategy8–9
(e) Describe any sensitivity analysesNA
Results
Participants13a (a) Report numbers of individuals at each stage of study—e.g., numbers potentially eligible, examined for eligibility, confirmed eligible, included in the study, completing follow‐up, and analysed9
(b) Give reasons for non‐participation at each stage6
(c) Consider use of a flow diagramNA
Descriptive data14a (a) Give characteristics of study participants (e.g., demographic, clinical, social) and information on exposures and potential confounders9
(b) Indicate number of participants with missing data for each variable of interestNA
Outcome data15a Report numbers of outcome events or summary measures9
Main results16(a) Give unadjusted estimates and, if applicable, confounder‐adjusted estimates and their precision (e.g., 95% confidence interval). Make clear which confounders were adjusted for and why they were included9–10
(b) Report category boundaries when continuous variables were categorised9–10
(c) If relevant, consider translating estimates of relative risk into absolute risk for a meaningful time period9–10
Other analyses17Report other analyses done—e.g., analyses of subgroups and interactions, and sensitivity analyses9–10
Discussion
Key results18Summarise key results with reference to study objectives10–12
Limitations19Discuss limitations of the study, taking into account sources of potential bias or imprecision. Discuss both direction and magnitude of any potential bias12–13
Interpretation20Give a cautious overall interpretation of results considering objectives, limitations, multiplicity of analyses, results from similar studies, and other relevant evidence10–12
Generalisability21Discuss the generalisability (external validity) of the study results12–13
Other information
Funding22Give the source of funding and the role of the funders for the present study and, if applicable, for the original study on which the present article is basedNA
Note: An Explanation and Elaboration article discusses each checklist item and gives methodological background and published examples of transparent reporting. The STROBE checklist is best used in conjunction with this article (freely available on the Web sites of PLoS Medicine at http://www.plosmedicine.org/, Annals of Internal Medicine at http://www.annals.org/ and Epidemiology at http://www.epidem.com/). Information on the STROBE Initiative is available at www.strobe‐statement.org. a
Give information separately for exposed and unexposed groups.

2. I feel better about myself because of this program
3. I am more aware of myself because of this program
5. I am given enough space by other people in this program
6. I better understand why I have used drugs and/or alcohol because of this program
8. I am supported to look after my health, financial and legal problems
9. I can get help for any difficulties I have
10. I know what the rules are and what will happen if I don't follow the rules
11. I think the rules make sense
13. I am provided with a schedule so that I know what to do with my time
14. I am provided with opportunities to exercise
15. I am provided with fresh fruit and vegetables
16. I think this place is clean and hygienic
17. I feel supported and understood by other people in this program
18. Staff treat me like a person and not an addict
19. I am supported to focus on my recovery
20. My family and friends have been provided with information about recovery
21. I am more able to cope with my everyday life outside the program
22. I have been linked up with other services to support me when I leave this program
23. I can get information from staff about where else I can go for help
